Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Damage Defects and Diffusion of Noble Gases in Minerals: He in Zircon as a Model System
Award.AbstractNarration:
The noble gases (helium, neon, argon, krypton, xenon, and radon) play a central role in understanding a wide variety of Earth and planetary processes, from tracing the origins of meteorites, to the differentiation of Earth's mantle, to dating the timing and rates of geologic processes. However, while we can now measure noble gases in minerals very precisely, our understanding of how they are incorporated into, migrate through, and are lost from minerals is simplistic and likely wrong in important ways. This work will use a series of novel experiments to understand the behavior of one noble gas, helium, in one mineral, zircon, to build a general understanding of noble gas behavior in other systems.

The ability to measure distinct isotopes of helium in zircon specimens with differing amounts and types of crystal defects and crystallographic orientations (as well as the widespread utility of the radiogenic He radioisotopic dating system) make this an ideal model system for this work. The project will focus on radiogenic 4He, as well as 3He and 4He implanted or generated in situ in zircons with varying amounts of radiation damage from both heavy nuclide recoil and light ion or neutron damage, and will also examine the effects of damage defect annealing on He behavior. These experiments will distinguish between the effects of damage defects as traps, tortuosity enhancers, and fast-paths at various levels of pro- and retrograde accumulation.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Noble gases (helium, neon, argon, krypton, xenon, and radon) in minerals provide some of the most useful tracers of geochemical and geologic processes in Earth and planetary science. They are either trapped in growing minerals or appear in them due to radioactive decay or other types of nuclear reactions that produce them in situ. Although many different techniques exploit measurements of the concentrations and isotopic compositions of noble gases in minerals, relatively little is understood about how noble gas atoms fit into and move through crystal structures or crystal defects, and how fast they can migrate as a function of time and temperature. Such understanding is critical for a wide range of applications including thermochronology and material science applications.

This project focused on understanding the behavior of one noble gas, helium, in one mineral, zircon, for two main reasons: 1) Helium (He) is the daughter product in the widely used zircon (U-Th)/He thermochronometer; 2) the crystal structure of zircon changes in complex ways as self-irradiation damage from alpha decay of uranium (U) and thorium (Th) accumulates and anneals. If we can understand the mechanisms and kinetic controls on He migration through zircon as radiation damage modifies the mineral, we will be able to more reliably interpret (U-Th)/He thermochronology and also provide a basis for understanding the behavior of noble gases in minerals across a spectrum of damage and defect densities.

Our study showed that He migrates through and is lost from zircon by thermally-activated volume diffusion, in contrast to its behavior in some other materials. In crystallographically pristine zircon, He diffusion is crystallographically anisotropic but becomes more isotropic as radiation damage accumulates in the crystal. At low extents of radiation damage, He diffusivity decreases and retentivity increases, but at high extents of damage this reverses, and highly damaged zircon releases He at high rates even at low temperatures. Although we don't yet know exactly why these changes happen, our work suggests that one possibility is that damage creates pockets of highly damaged regions from which He cannot escape, except at extremely high temperatures. Our study also showed how different types of radiation damage affect He diffusivity, and how to measure damage in zircon and associate it with particular crystallographic effects.

Radiation damage in zircon can be annealed, restoring regular crystallographic order and changing the behavior of noble gases. How fast radiation damage anneals in zircon as a function of time and temperature (the kinetics of annealing) has never been accurately determined, and this was one of the outcomes of our project. With hundreds of annealing experiments and spectroscopic analyses to measure the amount and type of crystallographic damage, we created a new kinetic model that can be used in combination with He diffusion kinetics to understand the thermochronologic significance of zircon (U-Th)/He ages. Our work will also form a foundation for understanding the behavior of other noble gases in other minerals.
